name: Old-Fashioned Oatmeal Brown Bread
description: Rich, dense, sweet -- enough said. Such a good toast bread!
recipeIngredient: 6 cups bread flour, or more as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Pour boiling water over oats in a large bowl; let soften, about 1 hour. Add molasses, butter, and yeast; mix well. Add flour, 1 cup at a time, mixing well after each addition until dough sticks together. Cover with a towel and let rise in a warm place until doubled in volume, about 1 hour.

Punch down dough and turn onto a lightly floured surface. Shape into 2 balls and let rest for 10 minutes. Form balls into loaves and place into the prepared pans. Cover loaves with a damp cloth and let rise until doubled in volume, about 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Bake loaves in the preheated oven until tops are golden brown, about 40 minutes.

review.reviewBody: very good bread!  like other post I proofed the yeast on its own (2 cups boiling water for oatmeal, 1/4 cup of water at 110 degrees plus 1 TBSP sugar for proofing yeast. Also I used 1/4 cup of vegetable oil instead of butter.

Delicious bread! Not overly sweet but it has a nice "dark" flavor due to the molasses. I used milk instead of water and a mix of all-purpose and whole wheat flour. I also halved the recipe to make 1 loaf. This bread is moist in the center with a nice hefty crust that is perfect for dipping into soup! Thank you for the recipe!
Not a fan. This bread came out super dense. The flavor was ok but it was so dense that if you didn't toast it you were eating a brick.

Turned out great. What I did differently was substitute 2 cups of bread flour with whole wheat and I did knead bread in mixer on dough hook and then by hand as I felt mixer was getting too much of a workout! Definitely a keeper.
Made it according to recipe and it was fabulous!

This bread tasted really nice. One kid complained that the crust was bland, but I thought it was okay. Baking notes: I only had to use 4 1/2 cups of flour. I drained the oats because they were quite watery after an hour of soaking. Maybe if I hadn't, I would have needed the entire 6 cups of flour. Also, after the first hour the dough did not rise a bit. I  took it out of the bowl and kneaded it for five minutes, separated it into two balls, kneaded those each for a couple of minutes, formed loaves and put them in their pans. I turned the oven on for 5 minutes just to warm it then turned it off. I put the loaves in there to rise and it worked. These steps worked an the dough doubled in size in abourt 40 minutes. Baked as per instructions.

I was in a bread making mood today so after making a French baguette i decided to try this recipe. I did cut the recipe in half to make 1 loaf--I love being able to do that by changing the serving size and letting Allrecipes do the math!!! I was very pleased with this bread! It is dense but still soft like a sandwich bread. I have all ready made sandwiches with it for the hubby's lunch. It did take awhile to rise...not sure if it was that the oat mixture was too cold when I started adding the other ingredients and the yeast was just slow to activate or it needs a touch more yeast? I love the taste of molasses in a bread and paired with oatmeal it is a winning combo! Thanks for the recipe Swaneeramsey!

This tastes great and I love the added fibre of the oats.  I was worried about proofing the yeast with the instructions provided, so I only put 2 cups of boiling water to soak with the oats.  For the remaining 1/4 cup of water, I used warm water, sprinkled one teaspoon of sugar and the yeast and let it sit for 10 minutes once the oats were done soaking and they I mixed it all together - this worked well! Light and flavourful, great for sandwiches or just eating toasted with a bit of butter.

We really enjoyed this. I added a TB of gluten and it holds together better than the other oatmeal bread I've made. To the person who thought it was too dense, make sure you spoon the flour into the measuring cup, and I still sift. I heated the cooled, soaked oatmeal to 110 degrees to activate the yeast. I also pulled the loaf out of the last proof after 10-15 min, covered it relatively tightly in the fridge overnight and baked the next morning (after letting it come to room temp). This will be our new go-to sandwich bread recipe. Yum!
